content:
ry 24
Early Access Review
								I Love the idea of this game and have put about 90 hours into it.  I believe in being honest so here is the good and the bad.First the bad, the game lags quite a bit if you don't lower view distances even with an I7-6900K, 64GB ram, 1080 video card, 3 SSD raid 0.  In other words a pretty decent gaming rig.  In order to get it to a playable state I had to drastically reduce viewing distances, turn off shadows, reflections etc....  I am able to play in the correct resolution for my monitor 3440x1440 but I had to turn most options fairly low before it was in a playable state.  Game is still in Alpha apparently, so may be this will be worked on and get corrected in the future through some sort of optimization.  Now for some of the good things about this game!  Character customization is superb, you can drastically change the way your toon looks when getting setup.  The devs have made massive updates to the game content wise since I first started playing it.  The game world looks substantially better than it used too in almost every single way imaginable.  I am not saying the graphics are F'ing amazing or something but they have improved and the world is not nearly as boring as it once was visually.Long story short it is a good indie title and definitely enjoyable if you have some patience.  Just remember your character sucks badly when you start and your best bet is running from danger to begin with.  You characters improve steadily through harvesting, fighting, running, carrying heavy objects, manufacturing etc... etc... if you like the idea of a squad based sandbox game with no real end game goal this could help you kill many an hour of boredom.

								recently i've been sinking dozens of hours into this and i decided i had to write a review. this is a openworld RPG with enormous freedom of choice.. have played since oldland (0.4 or something i think) and this game is what i like to see in RPGs..Story:this is a RPG that plays in a postapocalyptic wasteland thousands (?) of years after an extinction event and now people fight with swords and sticks because technology has mostly been lost..Freedom of Choice:tons of factions each with distinctions that set them apart (cannibals, zealots, ninjas etc..) so you can meaningfully change what kind of playstyle you want to use.. you can be a farmer, raider, trader.. kind of reminds me of x3 and other space-sim gamesHigh Customizability:choose between 4 Races and change your appearance with tons of slidersModding / Workshop:I have no experience with modding but with the tools provided by the devs (FCS - forgotten construction set) you can get at the guts of all the settings ingame that govern how the world and you / the NPCs workActive Development:this game has been here for quite some time and has already changed very much from the first versions and while the experimental branch (testing version) sometimes has bugs its very much enjoyable and improving all the time..

content:
2015
Early Access Review
								My take on Kenshi is a mixed bag.  Bottom line is I love the game but it's horrendously buggy and development is extremely slow.They bill it as an RPG with RTS elements, but it doesn't play that way for me.  I see it more as an RTS with RPG elements.  You scavenge materials, build a base, train recruits and laborers and defend or go on the aggressive.  It reminds me a bit of Earth 2150 in how each unit can earn experience and lvl up (the RPG aspects) while maintaining an RTS-like squad-focused feel.It's a lot of fun training your troops and building your town up.  But the bugs, oh my.  If you play the "stable" release, expect to crash randomly every hour or so like clockwork.  I honestly had better stability with the "experimental" opt-in steam beta branch, however some friends with similar rigs say they can't play the experimental version at all due to single digit frame-rates (it plays fine for me).  But either way you go, the sad state of pathing AI in this game really kills the joy.  Regular reloads when your own guys get stuck in the landscape and terrain and a constant spectacle of enemy units stuck on hills and corners.   This is by far the worst of the bugs, but there are lots of others.I really like the game and think it has awesome potential, but the state of development and the persistence of bugs through so many releases really has me discouraged.If you managed to pick it up on sale like I did and don't mind risking a small investment on a game with great potential, then go for it.  If you aren't willing to throw money at a project that may never be completed and has too many bugs to enjoy for any length of time in it's current state, then I suggest you wait and see what happens.  For me, I'd do it again.  I knew what I was getting into and the sale price of $10 makes it an acceptable risk.

content:
24
Early Access Review
								If you are looking for a game you can casually play for a few hours and be done with it, you should not buy Kenshi. This game takes a lot of time to get almost anything done. The huge world alone (and not even all of it is playable at this point) takes hours to explore, especially if you dont want your characters to starve on the way. The different zones make the world feel interesting enough, even though there are a lot of huge open spaces (perfectly suited to start a base).There are a lot of different ways you can play this game:Build a base with everything you need protected by a huge wall strong enough to withstand groups of raiders... orGather a few capable fighters to pillage camps, raider groups and whole cities if you are up to it... orMove swiftly in the shadows while you steal the most expensive goods to sell in another city where nobody knows (or cares) that the goods were stolen in the first place.But no matter what you do, be prepared to lose fights and almost get killed or enslaved over and over again, until you are an experienced survivor, because the start is very rough and the first few hours you will probably barely hang on to your life. But keep going, because once your stats allow you to withstand a proper fight, it will be so rewarding to pay back the beating.All in all this game has already very deep and intriguing mechanics and no matter what play style you choose, there is enough content to keep you busy for days. The development seems slow at first, but whenever there is a content update, it is usually pretty profound. The game is still a little glitchy, but there have been big improvements over the last year, so apart from occasional reloading, the bugs are not really much of a problem anymore.

content:
4, 2016
Early Access Review
								I remember seeing this game a couple years ago and being genuinely interested. I had a He-Man Lunchbox for a rig back then, so I figured it wouldn't run and held off on the purchase. Fast forward to my current rig, and now I still can't run it at max. But even with choppy frames it held my interest.The open world of Kenshi gives you an interesting post-post-apocalyptic backdrop where death is a constant threat, but survival is rewarded. Next to nothing remains of the old world, and there's been too many generations since for anyone to remember it or even know about it. The desert sands have left only unrecognisable hulking metal structures for scavengers to gather scrap iron, and the technologies of the past are only hinted about in tattered books that are sold at high prices. A fanatical religion dabbling in feudalism controls most cities and outposts, but searching beyond their military's grasp will find you in stranger places and their people, where you might find reward or a desolate death.In Kenshi, the player's role in the world is never specified. Your actions are completely free to you, but the world does react to them. What sets it apart from other sandbox is that NPC's can perform the same actions as you. Bandits will loot you after knocking you out, and factions may send trader's if your shop interests them. When you're researching walls and farming techniques, NPC outposts are studying the same, if not better, technologies. The Kenshi world is truly large, and set to be even bigger with future updates. There's nothing else really like Kenshi in similar genre's, and it's a truly ambitious idea. Only regret is not buying it earlier.

I honestly had better stability with the "experimental" opt-in steam beta branch, however some friends with similar rigs say they can't play the experimental version at all due to single digit frame-rates (it plays fine for me).  But either way you go, the sad state of pathing AI in this game really kills the joy.  Regular reloads when your own guys get stuck in the landscape and terrain and a constant spectacle of enemy units stuck on hills and corners.   This is by far the worst of the bugs, but there are lots of others.I really like the game and think it has awesome potential, but the state of development and the persistence of bugs through so many releases really has me discouraged.If you managed to pick it up on sale like I did and don't mind risking a small investment on a game with great potential, then go for it.  If you aren't willing to throw money at a project that may never be completed and has too many bugs to enjoy for any length of time in it's current state, then I suggest you wait and see what happens.  For me, I'd do it again.  I knew what I was getting into and the sale price of $10 makes it an acceptable risk.

content:
er 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								recently i've been sinking dozens of hours into this and i decided i had to write a review. this is a openworld RPG with enormous freedom of choice.. have played since oldland (0.4 or something i think) and this game is what i like to see in RPGs..Story:this is a RPG that plays in a postapocalyptic wasteland thousands (?) of years after an extinction event and now people fight with swords and sticks because technology has mostly been lost..Freedom of Choice:tons of factions each with distinctions that set them apart (cannibals, zealots, ninjas etc..) so you can meaningfully change what kind of playstyle you want to use.. you can be a farmer, raider, trader.. kind of reminds me of x3 and other space-sim gamesHigh Customizability:choose between 4 Races and change your appearance with tons of slidersModding / Workshop:I have no experience with modding but with the tools provided by the devs (FCS - forgotten construction set) you can get at the guts of all the settings ingame that govern how the world and you / the NPCs workActive Development:this game has been here for quite some time and has already changed very much from the first versions and while the experimental branch (testing version) sometimes has bugs its very much enjoyable and improving all the time..

content:
24
Early Access Review
								If you are looking for a game you can casually play for a few hours and be done with it, you should not buy Kenshi. This game takes a lot of time to get almost anything done. The huge world alone (and not even all of it is playable at this point) takes hours to explore, especially if you dont want your characters to starve on the way. The different zones make the world feel interesting enough, even though there are a lot of huge open spaces (perfectly suited to start a base).There are a lot of different ways you can play this game:Build a base with everything you need protected by a huge wall strong enough to withstand groups of raiders... orGather a few capable fighters to pillage camps, raider groups and whole cities if you are up to it... orMove swiftly in the shadows while you steal the most expensive goods to sell in another city where nobody knows (or cares) that the goods were stolen in the first place.But no matter what you do, be prepared to lose fights and almost get killed or enslaved over and over again, until you are an experienced survivor, because the start is very rough and the first few hours you will probably barely hang on to your life. But keep going, because once your stats allow you to withstand a proper fight, it will be so rewarding to pay back the beating.All in all this game has already very deep and intriguing mechanics and no matter what play style you choose, there is enough content to keep you busy for days. The development seems slow at first, but whenever there is a content update, it is usually pretty profound. The game is still a little glitchy, but there have been big improvements over the last year, so apart from occasional reloading, the bugs are not really much of a problem anymore.

Early Access Review
								First of all, my playtime is not accurate as I bought Kenshi well before it was available on Steam. Just want to add my thoughts about the dev cycle of this game. I rarely buy games before their full release given the risks of doing so. In the past years I have seen the dev team for this game go from basically one person's passion project to something more likely to be able to provide the grand vision the dev has. I have to say I have been impressed with this dev's committment to this title, even after making a good deal of pre-order/beta sales over the years. Integrity is important, and in my view this dev has done a good job working consistently to live up to his promises during this time. If watching a passion project game slowly grow is something you can be patient and handle, Kenshi is worth the ask price.tl;dr I do not regret buying this title years ago pre-steam. Would buy again. High-integrity Dev

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2016
Early Access Review
								The game can be described as Skyrim meets town building.I think the beauty of it is probably the early game struggle whether you're playing a single warrior or a weak bunch of settlers... in both experiences you'll only just be barely surviving and it's that edge of your seat moment to moment that makes the game so addicting. Yes in time you will become a master but it does the early game better than other survival rpgs in the genre. You will come to care about your characters if only due to all the extreme close calls you've been through with them.If you can imagine your most ideal open sandbox game lacking only a well written story or deep characters, well that's Kenshi.It does go from being one of the best games I've played to being a painful bug-ridden headache. But the Dev is very active adding a lot of new content quickly and likewise trying to fix bugs just as fast. I have a lot of faith in the Dev and the beautiful game he's creating and know it will be a labor of love that only continues to get better over the years.The highs for me overcome the lows. I'd recommend playing, it will be a game you remember fondly for a long time to come - provided you're lucky enough to have your first playthrough be a stable experience :)

content:
16, 2014
Early Access Review
								This, at the moment an early access indie game, is an RPG game with elements of RTS. You can play this game as one character, or play it as a group (at the moment maximally 20 peoples).None of your characters will be "unbeatable". Even your main character is just a man - and in the beginnings practically everyone will be better.Usually I start the game in hardest mode. Totally naked, with bad arm and a STICK. Yes - I can survive somehow... The best way how to show that any character can die is to give a preview of my game:I got around six peoples group and went from city to city. I walked too close to Cannibal outpost, and all my group except one girl had been prisoned. I walk then with that girl, and found a band of samurai's. And I made her to walk with them... Then I ordered all the rest of the band, to try pick-lock their cage to get out. one by one I managed to get out... One of the cannibals started to attack to my first character - to the AssassinLV, they beated him up... And were eating my character... After time He managed to get out... But My band was beated up - again but still alive... Later I was close to the city - when bandits attacked on my band... After many attacks AssassinLV were dying... Then that girl - who was not kidnapped, I ordered her to save my character, cause he had the bag full of trade... She managed to prevent AssassinLV from dying, but also she was noticed by other group of bandits... Then she was dying... And no one could been able to save her... She died - cause she was saving the other......

								So, I've been playing for 20+ hours now and I can Say I love to hate this game.Its a good RPG or Town management game that you have to manage squads, hunger and resources.Only downside, is that there is a tonne of stuff that needs to be fixed.All good games do take that time of course but when you are trying to farm and get raided and crash as it auto saves will drive you mad.Pros: you will lose your squad mates, you will want to build more, you have the freedom to mod the game for your self. BUGS THAT CAN KILL YOU, and holy arsehats they hate anything non-humanCons: the game is still being made, it doesn't run smoothy at first but does after a while. FPS drops alot in new areas. BUGS THAT WILL KILL YOUR COMPUTER, and lack of playable races(without you adjusting some stuff in the game editor)It has a lot of content, Its a solid game, needs alot of work but I think it will be worth it in the end. Limit your self in this game to see if you can do well. And have fun waiting for your guys to heal in cages.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ber 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								I gave this game a negative review about a year ago. The reason for that was at the time, the game had stuff to do but doing any of it required you to travel across a vast and featureless desert. I played for two hours and most of that time was spent doing almost literally nothing. It was a slog. I didn't mind the difficult and unforgiving combat, and the lack of ranged options only put me off mildly. It was that wide open desert, that vast expanse of nothingness seperating all that juicy interesting content.I noticed Kenshi in my library recently, and knowing well that it's developer was dedicated to making this game, I clicked it to see what had changed in the last year between now and when I had written that first review. As a friend of mine said, Development had gone from slow to frantic in that space of time. The old boring map was scrapped in favor of a far more interesting landscape. I installed the game and upon booting and making my character, my eyes were met with far more than brown sand and nothingness. The landscape is clearly still a wasteland, but it is now filled with interesting flora and fauna, and dotted with the twisted metal wreckage of some long gone peoples. I actually WANT to see this new world that Kenshi's creator has put foreward. That alone is enough for me to turn a thumbs down into a thumbs up. Apart from that, the game also features several races and female characters now. Sneaking and theft are a thing. Ranged combat is still not planned except for as mounted crossbow emplacements, which irks me a bit but not badly. Some of the stuff I didn't get to see before has become more accessable thanks in part to a landscape which isn't ballachingly tedious and boring to cross. The UI is also a lot more attractive and fitting.As a final note from my new experiance with Kenshi, I entered a town and immediately some preist told me I was a ♥♥♥♥♥ and needed to repent the darkness in my heart. Also, Someone shouted that some bandit nearby was "possessed by skeletons!" I know that one of the races is called "skeletons" but at the same time, I find the concept very funny.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								my my where to begin... this game is over 9000% early access (strange bugs, horrible pathfinding, very little variety in anything, very few updates, so many unexplained crashes) and yet... it appeals to me like very few other games have. i mean when you first jump in the game is hard as diamond and as rough as sharks skin and more brutal than dark souls but i think it really sets the mood.the game takes place on some sort of desert planet full of bandit groups, thugs for higher and shabby towns. its survival of the fittest and you better hope you and your crew are fit to survive.Pros:-completely open ended gameplay (you want to murder and cage every npc in a particular town? if your characters are strong enough then by all means!)-super in depth damage system (some bandit breaks both your legs? prepare to crawl on home boy, and pray that you don't lose em!)-build your own town/outpost (for training, crafting, and trading)-lots of crafting to be done-super in depth character creation (can also be used on newly recruited characters)-indication on the hud on who is being aggroed allows the easy snapping to any battle situation no matter what you are doing with verry little load time (like if you have 3 units running weapons to a nearby town for trading when suddenly a group of bandits shows up to your town)cons:-some structures can not be deleted-its not entirely clear whether or not your machines are not working because you don't have any power or they are full of junk at first glance-some of the UI is cut off-fast forward not fast enough (i don't want to watch my guy with broken legs carrying tons of stuff and an unconscious ally inch along the barren desert for hours looking for a town with a bed)-beds are easily exploitable     -if you have no cash or the bed is not public you can just pick someone up and lay them on the bed and it just works        -you can place NPCs with bounties who are "dying" in beds to prevent them from kicking the bucket and as an added bonus they also won't take any ♥♥♥♥ from guards who will be aggroed on them until they are removed from the bed(s)-very peculiar bugs (one that comes to mind is my armor smith somehow getting a stack of 40000 iron plates and another stack of the same size in the container i was keeping them in when he only had time to make 40 or so of them and his AI constantly taking way more that the armor making station can hold and stopping work on armor production as a result)-SUPER ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PATHFINDING!- one of the towns has 2 gates however one of them is blocked by a poorly made hill or something and the pathfinding dictates that they exit the other gate and go all the way around the outer town wall just to get to where they are going.-super steep learning curve-amazingly slow pace-HaVOK physics engine makes ragdolls look silly (even the dev made fun of it on twitter)-strange bugs with carrying people some distance and later dropping them-job allocation not clear enough (and for the longest time i didn't even know it was a thing making for a lot of tedious micro management)if you don't mind bugs and don't have interest in any finished games at the moment: get itif you do mind bugs or are looking at other games that are complete: go get those other games! its early access (at the time of writing this its actually in alpha) its not done and many of the cons i listed may be fixed by the time it actually comes out. so for you guys i would just wait until then.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
er 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								A one of it's kind genre of a game. Open World RTS RPG ect ect. The work on the game is quite fast (considering the features added all the time) and was slowed down by a huge amount of work on Pathfinding, which is finally done. In the meantime, they've been adding animals, random insult generator, and all sorts of fun stuff to their dev build in preparation for the finished pathfinding. I found the game fun back in the earliest stages of alpha, without sound, great graphics, or any polish at all. It was buggy but fun then, now the bugs are fewer and the fun is far greater.The limitations for the game are slowly getting reversed, and the game is becoming more grand by the day, with lots of dev updates and supports. The community is still small, meaning it's a lot easier to get a message across to the devs if you are feeling concerned. Overall, this is my all time favorite strategy game, start the game with a stick and become a martial arts master who runs a fortress with well armed squad of companions who tear up all sorts of bandit life in the wastelands.The game is great, but it's only gonna get better from here!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								 Kenshi deserves your money. Not only does the store page entice buyers, but it seems that the devs are actively listening to their buyers and are updating the game on a semi-regular basis. I owned this game when all I had to work with was a barely functional "promise" that, for the most part, held up and made an enjoyable "God game". Now the 'one-man' dev team has escalated into an actual team, there is actual music and sound, base defense, talk of a stealth/interogation mechanic, and wild animals! This is more than I asked for and I thank the devs personally for making this game and continuing to improve upon it.

content:
ry 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have played over 40 hours and so far I had a nice ride. Here´s my review:good graphics and setup. the character design and customization is neat, although I played zoomed out most of the time anyways. nice ideas and gameplay when it comes to base building and crafting. pretty good production chains. very nice concepts in this game. I love the post-apocalyptic-style of world design. atmoshpere-wise this really stand out.BUT... and there´s always a but it seems:( i know it´s early access , I get it. I never expected a finished game. it´s not that I bught it without having experience with other EA titles.)1. core mechanics not working or not working consistently enoughthis one is my main concern. workers forget their jobs, which means you end up a lot of micromanaging individual group members. also pathfinding and collision is a mess sometimes. even the workaround (which are offered, that´s a plus) don´t work consistently2. slow development cycles. the game is in development, which is nice. but so far I have experienced only one real update. the devs are in contact with the playersm which is nice. but I wonder how this game will ever pick up some momentum and gain some ground. basically from my standpoint, i couldn´t care less about great char graphics and player customization... thats all icing on the cake once its baked and finished to eat. but pathing, collision and AI behaviour is so essential for this kind of game that it needs to get taken care of asap. and when  Í read on the forums that some core game bugs are dependent on the actual game engine chosen for the game, I am prone to believe that maybe the have chosen the wrong engine....its been a good expense/reward scenario for me. I don´t mind spending the money as the time I played was great. but there´s no poin fo rme in keeping playing right now, because of the points mentioned before. keep in mind: it´s early access. so if you want to support the game and idea behind it (like I wanted to):buy it. its a good investment as the game itself will be sweet once it´s far more advanced. whenever that might be though...

content:
6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Update 10/07/15Kenshi has gone through a massive bug bash and is now far more playable than ever before. It is still missing the complete world map and still needs more content, but the majority of the bugs i mentioned in my review are now squashed! Kenshi has all the potential to be a great game, possibly even Warband great.At the moment it is fun but with no real longevity and a lot of bugs. This is to be expected in any Early Access game and as more content is added and the bugs are slowly squashed the game will only get better.Pros* A different play style - the world is cruel and you are but a grape waiting to be stamped on. (being beaten to a pulp by a group of starving homeless people with sticks, wearing pajamas is a cruel start to any game.)* Excellent damage system - limb damage and animations.* Base building (leads to CTD's at the moment but you can still experiment.)* The beginnings of an economy, with many items to purchase, craft and sell. (selling is a little bugged and not fully implemented yet.)* Open sandbox world - with the promise of many more biomes to come (currently there is only one flavor, desert!)Cons* Bugs glorious bugs! - CTD's every hour or so in the stable version, less to none with experimental, but a boat load of others such as NPC's getting stuck everywhere.* Without quests, faction relations and other planned features the game can get a little repetitive after 4-6hrs. (you will need to create your own adventure.)* Thrown in at the deep end - steep learning curve (can also be seen as a pro!)* Slow developmentMy main issue with Kenshi, and i believe the only reason you should not buy it if you like this type of game is the slow development speed. I cope with this because i really do believe in the devs and understand that this was a 1 man show for a long time and that this is their 1st project together. Everyone has to start somewhere! But because of this big bugs, such as the memory leaks and pathfinding are taking a long time to squash!So, should you buy Kenshi? If you like open world RPG squad management games... then it all depends how patient you are..... if you are not, then i would wait, there is an option on the Kenshi website to receive an email when the game is fully released.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
y 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'll write a short tale on how I became Hitler of Kenshi, the human experimenter.My journey began in wanting to be the world's greatest swordsman. So naturally I studied how to increase my combat skills. It says in the description of leveling up your combat skills, such as katana, dexterity, offense, and defence to fight stronger opponents than you in order to gain a bonus in leveling them. But, the obvious problem to that is when fighting stronger opponents you run a very high risk of dying. So I took on a passive approach. In the beginning I aggroed stronger mobs into friendly cities in order to maybe get a hit in between the crossfire. After the fighting was over I looted and bandaged the mob. Then I realised something, if the mob were not armed (because I looted them) they cannot fight back. Thus I learned a faster method to grinding my skills. Every once in a while I would get hurt so I ran to the local inn and rested my injuries. There I wondered, if I can rest my body faster this way, can I rest the bad guy's bodies? Of course I can. So I started making a human farm of looted enemies where I would beat them to unconsciousness, put them on a bed, then beat them to unconsciousness when they got better. But, the story doesn't end here. Later when I was building my village I noticed I can construct prison cages. What originally started out as a simple outpost for researching weapon crafting, turned into a human livestock factory of caged samurais and holy paladins where they would be beaten to unconsciousness every momment they are awake.tldr: I made a post-apocalyptic japanese concentration camp.9/10 (1- for the damn glitches, go finish the game)

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
26, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is one of the few early access titles I've not regretted picking up early. It delievers a decent level of content already with a lot more promised on the horizon, and it actually abides by the spirit of what early access is rather than just being a sort of super early preorder; the developer actually uses community feedback to determine what features to focus on.The game itself is also very engaging, but that's more a matter of personal preference. At its core it's primarily a sandbox game (and as far as I'm aware the first sandbox game to feature primarily desert, which strikes me as odd; think of the symbolism!), though at the moment it isn't as flexible as you'd expect a sandbox game to be. Even in early access, however, there is a decent level of easily accessible moddibility to be found. You can tweak and create weapons, NPCs, characters and even build NPC towns and modify the base mechanics of the game with a simple and relatively straightforward GUI.There is unfortunately not much more to say about the game at this stage because it is still early access and seemingly a long way off from release, which may be enough to put a lot of people off. Let me repeat because it can't be overstated: this game is made by an incredibly small team (it was a team of one for a long time) and it isn't likely to be finished in 2014, maybe not even in 2015. But it's already a fun game at its core if you like squad based RPGs or town building simulators or a mix of both, and it is steadily progressing. I also expect that over the coming year it'll start seeing some decent modding.

content:
er 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								To preface this review I would like to say,  "I really did not want to rate this game negativly. I also understand the early access stance of the game" It has a bold and unique style. And presents great "Potential" for gameplay. Many systems are implimented and more will be added. The game handles adventure and  the life of a wonder very well. These aspects will get even better with the new map. This is were my issue with the developers priorities come in. Far more resources need to go to bug fixing at the moment before adding new content. The second you start trying to build any mildly complicated base you will be in micro managing hell. Characters commonly get stuck  when depositing items into storage, get stuck under the stairs of buildings, randomly get their position confused and think they are outside a gate (this one is a little wierd), characters fill their inventories with ♥♥♥♥ when the container they are trying to hall to is full (I could probably fix this one if given access to the code. Check if their is space to stire the item in before allowing a character to pick up items from the original container. Items currently being hauled there by any any other character assigned to the task of auto hauling are counted into this total as well. They would still have issues if the player fills the container they are going to manually, but it is a start.), river raptors congregating at the base door and glitching through. Most of the issues involving characters being stuck can be fixed by reloading saving and loading the game. Until the game crashes as a result of this.

er 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								A very fun and addictive game a cross between stratergy and survival game genre. You can choose diffrent sceneries to start your story all of which add diffrent difficulties and fun to the game for example one spawns you in the middle of a camp of cannibils in which your be knocked out and have to escape, Another starts you off with a bunch of freedom seekers wanting to start their own town with a few supplies to get you started. This game adds a lot of replayability and freedom it has a few bugs here and there but it has a lot of promise and in this stage i find the game very fun and addictive.  One of my favirote features is the body health feature which if a body part gets damaged too much it will effect how you move and behave like holding your stomach from being damaged in the torso or being damaged on the leg causes you to limp which adds a dramatic feel to the game trying to limp to safety to a town or your outpost from bandits. this game still gets updated and improved on and i'm excited about seeing the future content they are lining up for this gem of a game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Update: April 6, 2016The Beta landed on 4-1-16 (EST) and already there have been no less than nine (9) hotfixes. The map is long and dark and full of mystery. All of the game mechanics are being refined. I know it seems to be a bit assholish to declare one's self correct, but, I was right about this one. Kenshi is an absolute joy, even when it is killing me. Its difficult nature lends to its developing world. Its unforgiving nature challenges the Player in ways that almost make her quit. Yet, she can't. Because the world of Kenshi is so beautiful and full of challenge. I highly recommend this game.Update: March 31, 2016Gotta say, I am super psyched for the beta release that is incoming. I have logged at least 150 hours since I wrote about my initial reaction to the thing that is Kenshi. I say 'thing' because this game is quite unlike anything I have ever played before. Yet, it is something I have always wanted as a gamer ever since I can remember.It scratches an itch that I've had for years. It combines sand box with squads and squads with player characters. It merges tower defense with  world domination. Troop dispositions and enemy  patrols so seamless, you might have died and gone to Heaven. But no. There is no Heaven in Kenshi. You could build a haven though, if you live long enough...There are strange beasts that roam the lands, looking only to pick off your weakest squad member. Leviathans prowl the dunes searching for... I don't know what... Best hope your haven isn't in their path.There are roving bands of dispicable men who would surely cut your throat as soon as rob you.There are strange tribes of what once were people who seek only to sate their hunger in this wasteland. I have grown used to dealing with the Cannibals, but, I wonder what brings them this far South? A lack of meat, maybe. Or perhaps they wish to test me and mine's swords...The Lo-Fi folks have lovingly and diligently crafted an amazing game. I have had a ton of fun playing it over the years. Yes, development has been "slow". But, damn if it didn't develop!!!I wish nothing but the best for Lo-Fi and thank them for the amazing times I've had playing in their world.After only an hour and a half, I can say without a doubt that this charming game is a gem and one I will enjoy watching develop even further.There is some nicely layered gameplay here with the RTS styled squad-based combat, base building and research opportunities. I have only skimmed the surface of this game but I can already tell I have many hours of fun ahead as I develop my army, base and economy.With the currently ongoing STEAM sale of Kenshi, I'd recommend jumping in now to support the developer in bringing this game to fruition as the little online research I have already done reveals that there is much more fun to be had in the comming months!

content:
y 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								This concept is the best i've ever seen, hands down. Love it.INSTA FANBOY, of the concept!!!I'm not even going to list to many of the bugs and flaws...because it's still in an alpha/beta  stage,and has been so for a long time.7 years + mostly with one guy working on it.Biggest Cons imo are,Lack of Heavy armor types/skinsNo AXESNo Maces,hammersNo bows/ranged combat..is planed tho on the roadmap.lack of buildingsBuilding walls is so broken its sad after countless fixes over the years including the new beta build.Men building the walls bug getting stuck in place or just will not build them etc.Can run through walls.(will be fixed )Even with chase disabled your men will chase enemy and start to spread out across the landscape.Game needs a stand ground or hold postion option for squads.The lag is real,game needs to be optomized.The stuff that makes this game just Great.(really to much to list)You can set up bases anywhere you want and as many as you want.Have up to 30 men in your faction,you must arm them and train them(this number will go up during beta maybe,if not easy to mod or DL a mod off the workshop)Buy and sell  goods.NPC SHOPS WORKCan have pack animals so far Bulls are in gameCan have dogs.Craft yourself and your men swords and armor.Huge open would. check the roadmap on their website.(Google LO-FI games.)The combat  is good,lacks good sounds tho.You can hardly hear any combat sounds in general.Hard at first, after maybe 10 hours or less becomes a cakewalk till more things are added.(that is if your starting guy or men are built up enough and have not been KILLED!!!)Each of your men have about 40 or so skills,its pretty crazy that you can lv up.Lots of research trees to upgrade everything.PERMA DEATHImport to a new world(map) with your squad you had from other saves...Steam workshop-modsCreate mods with the FCS,comes with game.Overall tho this game is cool and worth the time.Play this games experimental build that way you can play with all the new stuff before it gets added into the "stable build" the games gonna crash no matter what build,so imo its better to see all that the game has in it.After playing on the new map a bit,94hrs+ so far...got to say its looking good lacks flat areas worth building a nice looking base.I give the games concept a 10/10  the build 7/10 so far. Worth the 20 bucks as there is nothing like this one.

content:
y 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Update: April 6, 2016The Beta landed on 4-1-16 (EST) and already there have been no less than nine (9) hotfixes. The map is long and dark and full of mystery. All of the game mechanics are being refined. I know it seems to be a bit assholish to declare one's self correct, but, I was right about this one. Kenshi is an absolute joy, even when it is killing me. Its difficult nature lends to its developing world. Its unforgiving nature challenges the Player in ways that almost make her quit. Yet, she can't. Because the world of Kenshi is so beautiful and full of challenge. I highly recommend this game.Update: March 31, 2016Gotta say, I am super psyched for the beta release that is incoming. I have logged at least 150 hours since I wrote about my initial reaction to the thing that is Kenshi. I say 'thing' because this game is quite unlike anything I have ever played before. Yet, it is something I have always wanted as a gamer ever since I can remember.It scratches an itch that I've had for years. It combines sand box with squads and squads with player characters. It merges tower defense with  world domination. Troop dispositions and enemy  patrols so seamless, you might have died and gone to Heaven. But no. There is no Heaven in Kenshi. You could build a haven though, if you live long enough...There are strange beasts that roam the lands, looking only to pick off your weakest squad member. Leviathans prowl the dunes searching for... I don't know what... Best hope your haven isn't in their path.There are roving bands of dispicable men who would surely cut your throat as soon as rob you.There are strange tribes of what once were people who seek only to sate their hunger in this wasteland. I have grown used to dealing with the Cannibals, but, I wonder what brings them this far South? A lack of meat, maybe. Or perhaps they wish to test me and mine's swords...The Lo-Fi folks have lovingly and diligently crafted an amazing game. I have had a ton of fun playing it over the years. Yes, development has been "slow". But, damn if it didn't develop!!!I wish nothing but the best for Lo-Fi and thank them for the amazing times I've had playing in their world.After only an hour and a half, I can say without a doubt that this charming game is a gem and one I will enjoy watching develop even further.There is some nicely layered gameplay here with the RTS styled squad-based combat, base building and research opportunities. I have only skimmed the surface of this game but I can already tell I have many hours of fun ahead as I develop my army, base and economy.With the currently ongoing STEAM sale of Kenshi, I'd recommend jumping in now to support the developer in bringing this game to fruition as the little online research I have already done reveals that there is much more fun to be had in the comming months!

Early Access Review
								Worth the money I found. Ive got most of the game figured out other then the exploring part. I stuck to mostly town building. After that I made an army of people and made my way north to get a better feel for the fighting part. I found it usefull if you build resting outposts were ever you wanna send troops. All in all though I have to explore the combat and the world map more. For now though im taking a break so I can come back to the game later with a bunch more updates. Even if it wasant updated anymore I would be fine with whats is working and done so far. Really easy squad management. A little buggy for plotting movments on world map but eventually you figure out that there is certain points that work. If  you try to really far spot on the map you squads might not make it. As for graphics I actually really like it. I always enjoy all the detail off how diffrent some of the areas look. Its nice that its not some generated map for once. Worth the price! Its a game that I know I will always play.

content:
y 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has come a long way from its humble beginning. Even at the early stage it was very playable. Since then more features and improvements have been made. I like the fact that the dev does not rush things and in doing so I can see this game having a very large fan base when its finally completed. Its difficult to describe this game accurately as it contains many well thought out ideas. Its a great combination of things and because death comes swiftly to the unwary you actually start to care about each individual member of your group. They are vulnerable like any human and require training and experience. As this takes time you can get quite upset should one day your group get attacked by a large group of bandits and many members die or become seriously injured. Its this level of detail that makes the game so rewarding because you have to actually think rather than just throw a bunch of disposable, easily respawned soldiers into battle as you would in other RTS games. In Kenshi a human life is a valuable commodity.

content:
14
Early Access Review
								It took me a long time to decide to buy Kenshi a year ago or so. I was really intriged by this game I've never heard of before and that poping up in my steam suggestions. After reading some reviews and watching some gameplay videos I decided to risk a 20$ on this wierd looking game. Had this game for a while now. And I can say I really really like the skill system. It's a lot of fun to start with your weak-♥♥♥ squad and struggle to build a settlement that will survive a starving bandits raid. I had my main character becoming a martial art expert by kicking my bandit prisoners' asses on a daily basis. Said prisoners in return improved their defence skills, making it more chalenging for my character. Profit. I gave them little names.Of course the game is still in developpement and new features are still appearing and bugs are getting fixed as time passes, so I don't really mind if it's not as polished as you would expect from regular game. The gameplay is lot of fun, once you understand what the hell is going on, and the universe/lore of the game is truly unique and fascinating. I did not regret buying it.

content:
er 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Kenshi hates you and will punish you for every terrible thing you’ve done in your life.It will sometimes bring its wrath down upon your unsuspecting character right out of the gate and other times it will bide its time, waiting and watching you as you build up your perfect village, before it crushes you into the sand of its hauntingly beautiful world.And that’s just one of the reasons it’s so great.At its core, Kenshi is an open world group survival simulator. You begin the game with up to five characters and your goal is to keep them alive, heck maybe even try to get them to prosper in the Japanese themed post-apocalyptic world. This is by no means easily done – your characters start out pitifully weak and even a starving bandit can (and will) beat you half to death on his way to the shop before leaving your broken mewling body lying in the sand hoping you don’t bleed to death. Which brings us nicely onto death. Losing in a fight doesn’t mean death in Kenshi, it means you’re left lying in a pool of blood. Often you’ll recover on your own and limp painfully away but even if you don’t, all you need is a single member of your group to get back to his feet and he can then run around giving medical aid to everyone. Assuming you have a medical kit. You really should have a medical kit.With your character created (from a selection of origins, ranging from easy to hard – though easy isn’t all that easy) you can choose what you want to do. Do you want to hunt down bandits, loot them and sell their gear? You can do that. Rid the world of cannibals? That too. Become a trader, ferrying goods from town to town or even start your own village to try and make your way in the world.Whichever option you choose there will be a host of enemies that want to stop you achieving your goal and they will descend upon you time and time again. Interestingly, the initial point of the game is the hardest – being poorly equipped and rubbish at everything means that anyone passing can mug you. As the game progresses you hire additional mercenaries and gain skills, perhaps a fortified town with nitro-powered crossbows all around the walls; which means that the difficulty curve is strangely reversed – the game starts hard but becomes much easier later on.Despite its roleplaying open world sandbox style, the game which Kenshi struck me as most similar to was X3 (Not X4. That was a travesty) in that you are provided with a world where you may live however you want to, and expand to become whatever you want.The graphics of the world are nice if a little sparse. The world is a barren desert and there’s little to see when travelling from one town to another. At first this sets the mood quite nicely in that it’s a barren world that’s harsh and unforgiving, but this feeling drains away after a while since there’s little change and not a lot happening. There are bandits, traders, cannibals, and all sorts of factions, but no other signs of life – I’d have liked to have seen something like mutated scorpions, giant radioactive yaks, or even an occasional cow to give the world more life. Additionally the user interface is extremely basic in looks if not function – I’d very much like to see a more graphical interface rather than the generic default grey boxes.This is Alpha though, and there is a brand new world on its way with new biomes and, hopefully, wildlife that will serve to bring the world to life.Progression is through doing. There are a host of skills related to survival and combat and each skill is improved by doing work in that skill – the Engineer skill, for instance, is improved by building things. There are also three stats; strength, toughness, and agility, and these too are improved by doing things related to the stat – Toughness is increased by getting your face kicked in.Sound is still somewhat lacking; there is a pleasant music track throughout but ambient sounds – the hum of generators or creaking of windmills – is noticeably missing.I definitely recomend this game but, if you do get it, prepare to spend some time looking at your character whimpering and  gushing vital fluids.

content:
25, 2016
Early Access Review
								0.74.somethingStarted out as a man with the sword of the gods;.....5 min in: gets beaten up by starving thugs with iron sticks (there were 6 of them!!!!);10 min: limped back to city and payed outrageous bed rental for healing purposes(ONLY);12 min: goes to bar and made a friend by paying them(thats how you get friends in life if you have no choice);15 min: finished customizing friend;20 min: ninjas fight the town guards;22 min: rob ninjas for thier clothes and weapons;23 min: sold whatever not needed;24 min: ventures out for hours and builds a city and made a mercenary group named Band of the Hawk;27 min: get attacked by giraffe thingy??? barely survives....again;Hours upon hours in : Strong thriving, never seen much wildlife;*updates to latest update*started as a group of 5 robot nobodies;5 min: gets torn apart by giant giraffe bird things;restarted with another group: torn up by Giraffe birds known as beak things (lone survivor watched in horror as his comrades were left dying near the beak things sleeping on top of them;third group: survived and spent hours building a house with crossbows on top;hours: no more beak things HUNT THEM ALLL (just not on foot they are deadly);10/10 would get devoured (BROKEN!!!) by beak things in a harsh land again In all serioness this is a game that will stomp you down if you dont play it smart, but it is redicously fun and i can recommend it and the dev are working hard, trust me i follow their blogs. AND REMEMBER its an ALPHA its not perfect it can stress you out with the ocassional bugs and graphics card death threats (never really happens at all its just me i swear) but its great in my opinion, Keep up the good work Lo-Fi, keep it up.

								Hi eveyone,first of all i have buy this game 3 years ago haven't played it much until 0.70.x it was nice back then with lot of potential, but too many bug and lack of content/feature.The game just pass from alpha to beta [0.90.x] i decide to go back and see what's new and how the game evolve, and i need to say it's AWESOME, according to the fact that the game use ogre engine wich is not the best 3 d engine it's a really old open source engine update by it's community for the most part and according to the fact there only few dev maybe 10 ?anyway, there still some bugs there still need some optimisation and some feature not implemented yet or partially implemented but from previous alpha stage there as been so many improvement, if you like sand-box open world squad go ahead you will not regret it and for the price 15 $ IT TOTALLY WORTH IT.I f you read this it's beacause you ask yourself if you should buy it or not and like i said if you like sand-box open world roaming squad yeah you can blindly buy it, there is too many early acces game on steam but only a few are worth it this one is one of them.so would i recomend this game ? yeah defenetly the devs keep the game up to date and work hard to make this awesome game more awesome, modders will make it more fun and it's there is no other game like this.

content:
12
Early Access Review
								An amazing game of epic proportions.This game is not without flaws, first of all. If you have a slow computer or laptop you should expect frequent freeze-ups and even crashing. If you have a decent driver and a decent computer then you should be fine.Onto the good things, this game is incredibly difficult, you'll die or lose several times before you develop a gameplan to make it. Not to mention when you step into this game you'll be surprised to find yourself in an alien land both familiar and mysterious, you'll probably explore far enough to realize the inevitable nature of oneself. You are mortal, you are weak, and you are nothing compared to the beasts and residents of this land. You can be captured, imprisoned, enslaved, and you can break away from slavery and wander until you find a method of removing the binds.There is a silver lining though, being taken down isn't always the end, many roaming guards and factions will patch you up if they see you, other times your wounds may heal themselves and the more you get beat, the tougher you get. So being a legendary ninja or samurai is still possible.

								This is gonna be an painfully honest review. This is just my opinion of the game. Honestly I personally like the game, it's entertaining. So that may make me bias but let's just put the genera things about this game out there.1. It's a sandbox game.  Meaning there is no purpose, no goal, no direction what so ever. Talking of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you off this leads to the next thing perfectly.2. The bugs. Not just one or two bugs either. Just to name some you have people walking through your walls, bandits spawning as giant group in your base, your guys walking off, randoms guards attacking, yadda yadda yadda. Theres a good amount of bugs but thats just a warning. I would go on but i think you get the picture. If you have a calm head you may be able to stand this. If not then don't get it. Go play something else. The game is overall fun, but also makes a good rage bait. I like it personally but i would not recommend getting it just yet.

content:
r 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Started with a few people, made a bunch of wheat farms, and established a bread factory. After fending off tons of overly hostile beaked giraffes and endless patrols of king kong, finally got some walls and made a pretty respectable town. Every once and a while, characters would get stuck and glitch on many items (terrain, buildings, enemies)... all solved by picking up the char with another char and putting them back down (some kind of reset)All glitches aside, things were going great. Never mind the random spawning of ♥♥♥♥♥ons of cannibals and hostile wildlife that made my characters constantly stop and battle (inside town walls). I ended up making 500k running my bread factory and selling excess armor/weapons from the smithy. SO I decided I would set out with my fairly rugged, well laboured, farmers and see what hell I could raise. I walked not even 200ft to see a char get stuck. WELL I try my normal technique of using another char to pick up char... etc. Hrm WHAT IS THIS!?Somehow, I managed to get no one unstuck and my entire squad stuck instead. Then my autosave kicks in...As I'm trying to problem solve...My previous hard save was from over 4 hours ago. I feel like I just lost time in my life I will never get back. Overall, very fun addicting concept, but with multiple years in, you'd think they would have character pathing and tracking down.

content:
r 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS REVIEWThis game has been in my library now for awhile and I'm cleaning up my reviews, here's how I feel after owning this game for over a year:The concept, the depth and the artwork are golden but why negative? They overhauled this game to what it seems to come back to the same conclusion, it's unplayable. The bugs, performance issues will slowly if not instantly ruin your game (mind you that this game is a grind, bugs and show stoppers will wash away hours of work). They have been adding to this game which is great but they still have yet to deliver something that's playable. Most of the previous positive reviews were more than likely from the previous build which was more playable to an extent***The game itself will be a masterpiece if its ever finished but thats where I give it a negative review, it felt almost complete before the overhaul now it feels like its taken a few steps back but with even more depth and with the scale I'm wondering if it will every be completed. I'd grab it on sale or hold off, its one of those games that wow you, you play, the bugs and un-optmized feel have you back shelf the game to only revisit. Devs are active but are quick to ban... recommend not bringing up bugs or scorn against this game or commenting on the active state of the game.Below is a response from a Dev/Moderator that I wasn't too fond of, if you have a questions and it can be generically answered by a moderator like below, you may see this again. Originally posted by Captain Deathbeard:This is what game development is like: -You've got a list of 100 features and 100 bugs.-Every time you add a feature, it adds another 50 bugs.-Every time you fix 10 bugs, you discover 3 more bugs.-Occasionally to fix one of the bugs you might need to totally restructure something. This will probably add 10 more bugs.-When you fix bugs people say "These updates don't do anything, where are the features?"-When you add features people say "Why aren't you fixing the bugs?"

content:
y 1
Early Access Review
								FIrst off, I have had this game for a good many years now; It has progressed so greatly that I feel proud when I play it now. Proud for the developers and proud of how I have learned the ins and outs of this game. This game started out pretty basic, just lots of sand dunes and hungry bandits everywhere. Slowly, a game started to appear out of the haze. Building towns, getting invaded, shop counters (still kind of broken, oh well) and then cannibals. Gotta love cannibals! Now the map expands and there are new places to uncover. I recently uprooted from one area into Holy nation land (Although they hate me) once I had a devoted military group. I have a base in on an island sorrounded by rivers and the holy nation must cross the water to get to me... Which is no easy feat while getting hit by mounted crossbows =)This game will kick your ♥♥♥ hard though. I started out in a setting that gives you a veteran soldier who is hated by the biggest faction in the game currently. It gave me a springbox to move forward though. I worked up his stealth and was able to kidnap a holy nation soldier in camp and use his armor as a disguise to get into their cities. Oh there are also raptors and giant turtles to kill and eat11/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do you like The SIms, or squad based RPGs in general (games where you can control multiple characters or individual ones each with their own skills, and statistics)Do you like Ninjas? Have you ever wanted to play a sims type game in a ninja / samurai filled apocalyptic world?this is the game for you, its a bit rough around the edges still, and sometimes the glitches can be quite frustrating But with the bad out of the way this game is a master class game that you should try. Favorite parts: The game plays without you and your characters are not "heroes" they are probably weaker than almost anyone you can encounter.. however they have the ability to grow depending on what you do. The game will not need you to start events, or to stop them. You are more of a drop of water in a big puddle. You can influence and affect what happens.. if a big band of bandits shows up at a city your base is near, they can take out the guards and shops, effectively neutralizing the town. Later a travelling group of lawmen might take it back.. either way, even if you could have changed the outcome, the game keeps playing. Your characters have stats in almost everything. if you want yout character to be stronger, give him or her a lot of heavy equipment and have them run around. Eventually their strength will increase. Speed is the opposite, have someone run around without anything in their bags and they will become more athletic and therefore faster. Laboring from mining, or smelting. Crafting from weapon or armor smithing. Medicine from healing. The characters become increasingly valuable as time goes on..The fact that you  can plop a town wherever you want, build walls, turrets, arm your soldiers with swords and armor and have your builders be guarded and automated with designated tasks is beautiful. Kenshi is absorbing, Rough, Frustrating, Comically suprising and has the potential to be an amazing game. Id say get it.. try it, support the devs and enjoy the process of their creation

								EARLY ACCESS REVIEWThis game has been in my library now for awhile and I'm cleaning up my reviews, here's how I feel after owning this game for over a year:The concept, the depth and the artwork are golden but why negative? They overhauled this game to what it seems to come back to the same conclusion, it's unplayable. The bugs, performance issues will slowly if not instantly ruin your game (mind you that this game is a grind, bugs and show stoppers will wash away hours of work). They have been adding to this game which is great but they still have yet to deliver something that's playable. Most of the previous positive reviews were more than likely from the previous build which was more playable to an extent***The game itself will be a masterpiece if its ever finished but thats where I give it a negative review, it felt almost complete before the overhaul now it feels like its taken a few steps back but with even more depth and with the scale I'm wondering if it will every be completed. I'd grab it on sale or hold off, its one of those games that wow you, you play, the bugs and un-optmized feel have you back shelf the game to only revisit. Devs are active but are quick to ban... recommend not bringing up bugs or scorn against this game or commenting on the active state of the game.Below is a response from a Dev/Moderator that I wasn't too fond of, if you have a questions and it can be generically answered by a moderator like below, you may see this again. Originally posted by Captain Deathbeard:This is what game development is like: -You've got a list of 100 features and 100 bugs.-Every time you add a feature, it adds another 50 bugs.-Every time you fix 10 bugs, you discover 3 more bugs.-Occasionally to fix one of the bugs you might need to totally restructure something. This will probably add 10 more bugs.-When you fix bugs people say "These updates don't do anything, where are the features?"-When you add features people say "Why aren't you fixing the bugs?"

content:
y 1
Early Access Review
								FIrst off, I have had this game for a good many years now; It has progressed so greatly that I feel proud when I play it now. Proud for the developers and proud of how I have learned the ins and outs of this game. This game started out pretty basic, just lots of sand dunes and hungry bandits everywhere. Slowly, a game started to appear out of the haze. Building towns, getting invaded, shop counters (still kind of broken, oh well) and then cannibals. Gotta love cannibals! Now the map expands and there are new places to uncover. I recently uprooted from one area into Holy nation land (Although they hate me) once I had a devoted military group. I have a base in on an island sorrounded by rivers and the holy nation must cross the water to get to me... Which is no easy feat while getting hit by mounted crossbows =)This game will kick your ♥♥♥ hard though. I started out in a setting that gives you a veteran soldier who is hated by the biggest faction in the game currently. It gave me a springbox to move forward though. I worked up his stealth and was able to kidnap a holy nation soldier in camp and use his armor as a disguise to get into their cities. Oh there are also raptors and giant turtles to kill and eat11/10

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do you like The SIms, or squad based RPGs in general (games where you can control multiple characters or individual ones each with their own skills, and statistics)Do you like Ninjas? Have you ever wanted to play a sims type game in a ninja / samurai filled apocalyptic world?this is the game for you, its a bit rough around the edges still, and sometimes the glitches can be quite frustrating But with the bad out of the way this game is a master class game that you should try. Favorite parts: The game plays without you and your characters are not "heroes" they are probably weaker than almost anyone you can encounter.. however they have the ability to grow depending on what you do. The game will not need you to start events, or to stop them. You are more of a drop of water in a big puddle. You can influence and affect what happens.. if a big band of bandits shows up at a city your base is near, they can take out the guards and shops, effectively neutralizing the town. Later a travelling group of lawmen might take it back.. either way, even if you could have changed the outcome, the game keeps playing. Your characters have stats in almost everything. if you want yout character to be stronger, give him or her a lot of heavy equipment and have them run around. Eventually their strength will increase. Speed is the opposite, have someone run around without anything in their bags and they will become more athletic and therefore faster. Laboring from mining, or smelting. Crafting from weapon or armor smithing. Medicine from healing. The characters become increasingly valuable as time goes on..The fact that you  can plop a town wherever you want, build walls, turrets, arm your soldiers with swords and armor and have your builders be guarded and automated with designated tasks is beautiful. Kenshi is absorbing, Rough, Frustrating, Comically suprising and has the potential to be an amazing game. Id say get it.. try it, support the devs and enjoy the process of their creation

content:
7
Early Access Review
								1.9 hours in(at the time of this review), I think its safe to say this game is worth it. After reading through the planned features on the main website, its clear the devs have  the potential to make this game a success.Its true, the start is hard. Especially if you're playing on rock bottom like me. But in time, each hour you survive, you get stronger and faster. While not being too powerful, this game teaches you how to be smart and humble. Don't be fooled by that herd of goats wandering aimlessly. To give you a visual of what its like in Kenshi, here's my first playthrough.>naked dude walking around>see group of people in the distance>'hello friends!'>nope, slavers.>'don't think about running!' 'C'mere meat!'>at first it was just one guy>whole squad joins in>1 blow to the head>KO>unconcious for 400 seconds>wake up>hungry, broken arm, bleeding head>reach lone shack>broke>see iron resource>its mining time!>8 ingame hours later>fed and recovering>mine some more>get iron stick>stats increase while mining(str and labour)>see goats>prepare to get sacrficed to okran! >whole herd attacks me>dying>in lone shack>some guy picks me up>im saved!>lolnope.gif>throws me outside>die outside of lone shack>endThats how exciting my life was in Kenshi. All in all, worth it.
